review.title: RDeepSense: Reliable Deep Mobile Computing Models with Uncertainty Estimations
review.abstract: Recent advances in deep learning have led various applications to unprecedented achievements, which could potentially bring higher intelligence to a broad spectrum of mobile and ubiquitous applications. Although existing studies have demonstrated the effectiveness and feasibility of running deep neural network inference operations on mobile and embedded devices, they overlooked the reliability of mobile computing models. Reliability measurements such as predictive uncertainty estimations are key factors for improving the decision accuracy and user experience. In this work, we propose RDeepSense, the first deep learning model that provides well-calibrated uncertainty estimations for resource-constrained mobile and embedded devices. RDeepSense enables the predictive uncertainty by adopting a tunable proper scoring rule as the training criterion and dropout as the implicit Bayesian approximation, which theoretically proves its correctness.To reduce the computational complexity, RDeepSense employs efficient dropout and predictive distribution estimation instead of model ensemble or sampling-based method for inference operations. We evaluate RDeepSense with four mobile sensing applications using Intel Edison devices. Results show that RDeepSense can reduce around 90% of the energy consumption while producing superior uncertainty estimations and preserving at least the same model accuracy compared with other state-of-the-art methods.

Although existing studies have demonstrated the e-activity and feasibility of operating deep neural networks based on definitions and embedded devices, they reduce the reliability of mobile computing models.

sections.heading: 3 RDEEPSENSE FRAMEWORK
sections.text: In Section 3.2, we introduce preliminary knowledge and perform the theoretical analysis of RDeepSense. We prove that RDeepSense is a mathematically sound method to obtain predictive uncertainty estimates. In Section 3.3, we introduce an e-effective and e-efficient approximation for RDeepSense to obtain predictive uncertainty estimates while running on resource-limited, embedded devices. In the rest of this paper, all vectors are denoted by bold lowercase letters (e.g. x and y), and matrices and tensors are denoted by bold capital letters (e.g. X and Y). sections.heading: 4 EVALUATION
sections.text: In this section, we evaluate RDeepSense using four mobile and ubiquitous computing tasks. First, we present the experimental setup for each task, including hardware, data sets, and baseline algorithms. Then, we evaluate the accuracy and quality of the uncertainty assessment. Next, we evaluate the derivation time and energy consumption of all algorithms on the test hardware. Finally, we evaluate and analyze the effect of the hyperparameter α in the training target function (18) on model performance, as well as the accuracy and quality of the uncertainty assessment.

sections.heading: 4.1 Testing hardware
sections.text: Our test hardware is based on the Intel Edison Calculator Platform [1]. The Intel Edison Calculator Platform is powered by the Intel Atom SoC 500 MHz dual-core CPU and has 1 GB of memory and 4 GB of ash memory. In fairness, all neural network models run exclusively on the CPU during evaluation in terms of inference time and energy consumption.

sections.heading: 4.2 Evaluation tasks
sections.text: We are conducting four experiments related to human health and well-being, intelligent urban traffic, environmental monitoring, and the detection of human activity with RDeepSense and other two state-of-the-art measurement methods to measure deep learning insecurity, as well as a statistical model. e experimental analysis of tasks and datasets are presented in this paragraph. e detailed statistical information on four datasets is presented in Table 2 • BPEst: Cu measurement of blood pressure by photoplethysmograms. e first task is to monitor lower blood pressure by photoplethysmogram from ngertip. e dataset was originally collected from patient monitors in various hospitals between 2001 and 2008. Waveform signals were sampled at 125 Hz frequency with at least 8 bit accuracy [21]. e photoplethysmogram from ngertip (PPG) and arterial blood pressure signal (mmHg) were sampled with 8 bit accuracy.

sections.heading: 4.3 Baseline algorithms
sections.text: We compare RDeepSense with other two states where the algorithm triggers a variety of uncertainties, with Monte Carlo, and Gaussian Process. e deep neural network algorithms, including RDeepSense, require the same neural network architecture. It is a 4-layer network with 500 hidden dimensions.

sections.heading: 4.4 Accuracy of prediction and quality of uncertainty estimations
sections.text: In fact, it is the case that most of us are able to move into another world, in which they can move into another world, in which they are unable to integrate themselves, in which they are able to live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they, in which they live, in which they, in which they live, in which they, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live.

sections.heading: 4.5 Inference time and energy consumption
sections.text: We compared the resource usage of each algorithm, including the inference time and energy consumption of individuals, which are two key topics for mobile and ubiquitous computer systems. All experiments are performed on Intel Edison with only one CPU as a computational unit. No further optimization is applied to any algorithms. Results of four tasks, namely BPEst, NYCommute, GasSen and HHAR, are presented in the size of training records that are impracticable.

sections.heading: 4.6 E ect of hyper-parameter α on model performance
sections.text: The hyperparameter α controls the tradeo between the optimization of the mean and the variance within the training target function (18), which can help to obtain a well calibrated uncertainty estimate. In this subsection, we evaluate the functionality of α and also provide information on the way of tuning α. For each task, we train RDeepSense with α = [0, α, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8, 0.9]. If α = 0.0, RDeepSense is trained by minimizing the negative log probability. If we increase the value of α, RDeepSense focuses more on the mean estimate instead of the negative log probability. To show the effect of choosing α on the quality of the prediction improbability, we show the negative log probability and the commission range (the range between the calibration curve of an algorithm and the optimal calibration curve) on a negative log probability.

sections.heading: 5 DISCUSSION
sections.text: is a paper that focuses on enabling neural networks to generate high-quality predictive uncertainty estimates in a theoretically sound and energy-efficient manner for mobile and ubiquitous computing tasks. Currently, RDeepSense can only support fully connected neural networks. However, it is possible to extend the two-step solution introduced in Section 3 to revolutionary and recurrent neural networks by replacing the original dropout operation with revolutionary dropout operations [16, 18] and recurrent dropout operations. However, two dropout operations can be Vol. 1, No. 1, Article 1. Release Date: January 2016. Convolutionary neural networks and recursive neural networks in Bayesian neural networks [16, 18] but additional dropout operations are needed to theoretically prove that the extended two-step solution can be equated to any neural network with a statistical model.

sections.heading: 6 CONCLUSION
sections.text: We introduced RDeepSense, a simple but effective solution that enables fully networked neural networks to generate well-calibrated predictive uncertainty estimates during model inference. RDeepSense is a computationally efficient algorithm that can deliver predictive uncertainty estimates with almost no additional effort in mobile and ubiquitous computing applications. Eoretical analysis also shows the equivalence between RDeepSense and a statistical model. We evaluated RDeepSense on four mobile and ubiquitous computing tasks where RDeepSense exceeded the most advanced baseline by showing small margins in the quality of uncertainty estimates while consuming the lowest amount of energy on embedded devices. In summary, RDeepSense is a simple, effective and efficient solution for mobile and ubiquitous applications to build reliable neural networks with uncertainty estimates.

Although mathematically grounded methods such as Bayesian approaches serves as powerful tools to estimate predictive uncertainties [11], Bayesian neural networks are computationally expensive to train and inference even for brawny servers, let alone mobile and embedded devices [43].

Although mathematically grounded methods such as Bayesian approaches serves as powerful tools to estimate predictive uncertainties [11], Bayesian neural networks are computationally expensive to train and inference even for brawny servers, let alone mobile and embedded devices [43].

For mobile and ubiquitous computing applications, although we can train the deep neural networks on brawny servers with powerful GPUs, running inference on mobile and embedded devices is dicult due to limited energy supplies and computational resources on such devices [56].

Firstly, RDeepSense uses a tunable proper scoring rule as the training criterion that signicantly mitigates the problem of underestimating predictive uncertainties in deep neural networks [17].
Secondly, since dropout training can be interpreted as “geometric averaging” over the ensemble of possible “thinned” subnetworks [2], RDeepSense applies dropout training instead of model ensemble.

metadata.abstractText: Recent advances in deep learning have led various applications to unprecedented achievements, which could potentially bring higher intelligence to a broad spectrum of mobile and ubiquitous applications. Although existing studies have demonstrated the eectiveness and feasibility of running deep neural network inference operations on mobile and embedded devices, they overlooked the reliability of mobile computing models. Reliability measurements such as predictive uncertainty estimations are key factors for improving the decision accuracy and user experience. In this work, we propose RDeepSense, the rst deep learning model that provides well-calibrated uncertainty estimations for resource-constrained mobile and embedded devices. RDeepSense enables the predictive uncertainty by adopting a tunable proper scoring rule as the training criterion and dropout as the implicit Bayesian approximation, which theoretically proves its correctness. To reduce the computational complexity, RDeepSense employs ecient dropout and predictive distribution estimation instead of model ensemble or sampling-based method for inference operations. We evaluate RDeepSense with four mobile sensing applications using Intel Edison devices. Results show that RDeepSense can reduce around 90% of the energy consumption while producing superior uncertainty estimations and preserving at least the same model accuracy compared with other state-of-the-art methods.
